div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: FATHY BEY ZAGHLOUL
div.p: The vigour with which the impending ap. pointment of Ahmed Fathy Bey Zaghloul to the post of Under-Secretary of State to the Ministry of Justice is now denounced by “AI Lewa” is an interesting indication of the inentality of some of our extremists. The fact that Fathy Bey was one of the five judges concerned in the Denishwai trial need not be accepted as the sole explanation thereof, for as one of our contemporaries recently remarked, neither Boutros Pasha Glali nor any of the | native officials connected with the trial and enquiry have had to endure the same obloquy as the future Under-Secretary of State The true explanation of the attitude of “Al Lewa" ies, in our opinion, in the fact that Fatby Bey,as a friend and follower of the late Sheikh Mohamed Abdou, Grand Mufti of Egypt, has never been in sympathy with the men who were the bitterest opponents of his intellectual leader and opposed his enlightened attitude with a determination worthy of a better cause Could Sheikh Mohamed Abdou have combined with his great qualities of head and heart a taste for violent and rampaging journalism on behalf of Pan-Islamic ideas or in support of the leader--and tyrant-of the Nationalist party, he might have won at least the outward support of the acolytes of "Al Lewa.” As it was, his intelligence and statesmanlike qualities forbade him to seek a cheap popularity, and in later years his progressive tastes, knowledge of the world, and respect for the dignity of his office were powerless to win him the respect of a noisy clique, whose motto, "Egypt for the Egyptians," has been already described as "Egypt for the Turks" and may henceforth be rendered "Egypt for our own friends." The appointment of Nationalists who are not members of a certain ring of extremists appears to cause our critics as great annoyance as the selection of British officials or of natives whose Jaympathies are avowedly with the existing order of things, and we should not be surprised

at the introduction in the near future of a new form of the agitation against the "dukhala," this time aimed against those who are guilty of the heinous offence of "intrusive" ideas. A thin veneer of European Liberalism bides the intolerant Conservatism of the extremist from the gaze of foreign sympathisers and itinerant M.P.'s, but those who are familiar with the facts of Egyptian life are not likely to be imposed op by cries for “Parliament," "Liberty,” and what not, when uttered by the most vigor. ous of xenophobes.

We recently expressed our satisfaction at the fact that our contemporary "Al Minbar" had requested some of the more vocal mombers of the Nationalist party to cease making themselves, and the cause, look foolish by amazingly comic demands. We hope our contemporary will go further and oppose the intransigeant attitude of "Al Lawa," which appears to require all prominent Egyptians to parade ideas entirely similar to those of Mustapha Pasha Kamel and Ali, his brother, if they are to obtain its support. At present there is a tendency to cry out on any appointment being made that A.or B is not a good National. ist, i.e., not a Nationalist on the lines of those aggrieved by his appointment. If, as we expect, the future policy of Lord Cromer will be to associate more and more Egyptians of ability and merit in the task of governing the sountry, it responsible posts, till now held by British officials, are to be given more frequently to native officials of good character and intellect, it will be somewhat disappointing to find a section of the Press clamouring and raging, not because certain posts have not been grapted to natives of the country, but because they have not been granted to the partisans of this editor or that orator.

div.head: CHRISTIANS IN THE LEVANT
div.p: Up to a few years ago France was the acknowledged protector of all the Roman Catholics of European nationality in the Near East, and the French Embassy was that to which missionaries of all nations turned when there was any dispute with, or complaint against, Turkey. But during the last few years, owing to the disputes with the Vatican, France has been losing that protectorate, and the Italian monks and missionaries have been transferring their interests to the protection of Italy. The Salesians began it towards the end of 1904, and then the Père Conventuels, or Cordeliers, in Turkey, who aro nowadays all Italians, followed their example. Towards the end of 1905 an agreement was come to between France and Italy by which those religious establishments which desired it were onabled to place themselves under the protection of Italy on due notice being given to France. There are two reasons for this state of things. The first is political, and has to do with the FrancoItalian understanding. Formerly there was intense rivalry between France and Italy in the Levant, but when France desired a better understanding with her neighbour, she gave way in this matter, and it should be noted that most of the transfers just registered are in Tripoli, which is within the Italian sphere of influence. The second reason is religious, and relates to the separation of Church and State in France, and more especially to the suppresrion of the French Embusøy at the Vatican, which makes it very difficult for France to exercise her protectorate. This cannot well be exercised without the concurrence of Rome, which hitherto has always upheld the protectorate of France against the claims of other Powers. The new policy is perhaps regrettable, but it is the natural outcome of the separation of Church and State in Franco,

div.head: Military Tournament
div.p: A shield presented by Sir T.R. Dewar will be competed for in the bayonet team combats at the forthcoming military tournament in Cairo and will be held by the winning team till the next tournament takes place.

div.head: Charity Performances
div.p: We are requested to draw the attention of our readers to the performance of "La Boheme" which is to be given at the Zizinia Theatre to-morrow evening in aid of the funds of the Maltese Benevolent Society. The performance promises to be a great success, nearly every one of the boxes and seats being booked.

div.head: Alexandria Follo Case
div.p: Sagh, Antonio Gauci Mamour of Attarin Caracol, who was tried a few weeks ago by a council of discipline for having received bribes and commited other irregularities, has been found guilty and sentenced to dismissal from the service. On appeal the special council confirmed the sentence depriving Mr. Gauci of the right to a half-pension.

div.head: Cairo Scientific Society
div.p: A meeting of the society will be held at the school of Medicine on Thursday, 28th inst., at 4 30p.m. The following communications will be given: "The Flow of Water in a Uniform Channel," by Mr. I. I. Craig ; "A new Topographical Survey of the Brain," by Dr. G. Eliot Smith ; "Description of the New Telescope at Helwan with examples of the Stellar photographs taken by its means" by Mr. B.F.E. Keeling

div.head: English Ladies Attacked
div.p: An attack by two fellaheen on two English ladie, the wife and daughter of a professor of the School of Medicine, is reported from Marg, where they had gone for an outing. After maltreating their victims the men robbed them of their valuables. The Moundir of Benhavon hearing of the outrage formed a cordon of guards around the locality and by this means suceeded in securing the aggressors. The jewels and a portion of the money they had stolen were found on them.

div.head: Accident at Port Said
div.p: As the Messageries Maritimes S.S. Yunnan was coming out of the Suez Canal yesterday to anchor in Port Said harbour she came right in the line of a boat laden with coal in which were eight men. The Latter, seeing that a collision was inevitable as the ship was close up, frantically waved their arms as a signal of danger. This action prevented the boat from advancing and as the steamer could not stop in time the former was run down and sank. The men were rescued by boats which came to their aid at once.

div.head: Anglo-American Ball
div.p: We beg to remind our readers that the Anglo-American Hospital Ball will be held at the Casino in the gardens of Ghezieh Palace Hotel at 10 p.m. on Thursday, March 7, under the distinguished patronage of the Countess of Cromer, Mrs. Iddings, Mrs. Bullock, Lady Wingate and other ladis of Cairo Society. We understand that already over 700 tickets have been sold and the ball promises to be the greatest success of the Cairo season. No one should fail to be present and especially as it may be almost the last time that the Casino will be available for entertainents of this kind. The Casino is admirably suited for a large ball and the scene there on the eveneing of March 7 will be a very brilliant and striking one.

div.head: Floating Exhibition for Alexandria
div.p: Alexandria and other Mediterranean ports are to be visited by an exhibition ship, which is to be fitted out with a view to gaining new outlets for French commerce. The vessel is to be arranged as a floating exhibition of products suitable for export and French manufacturers and merchants will be enabled to exhibit their goods and samples on payment of moderate charges. A number of salesmen, partly drawn from pupile of the commercial schools speaking at least two languages will be carried these being under the superintendence of experienced commercial travellers. In order to stimulate their zeal, all these employees will be paid on commission and the widest possible publicity is to be given to the vessel's expected arrival at the ports at which she is intended to call. At each place the salesmen will present their samples to the various buyers, and transmit the orders they may obtain to the head office which will see them carried out. A series of receptions and fetes are to be held on board with the view of attracting customers.

div.head: BIG LAND DEAL
div.p: The property of the Gabbary Syndicate, consisting of 537 feddans, has been sold to Mr. Charles Bacos for £1,250,000.

The syndicate (composed of Messrs. Stagni, E A Benachi, and N. E. Tamvaco) has made a very favourable sale and the purchaser has also secured a promising bargain as we understad that he purposes developing his newly acquired of Alexandria, in which venture his prospects appear excellent.

div.head: BUILDING LANDS OF EGYPT
div.p: Four members of the board of directors of the Building Lands of Egypt, Mr R. Abby, Mr. E. Karam, Mr. Suzzarini, and Mr. Houri, resigned yesterday. The manager, mr. Alfred Citti, resigned on the 22nd inst. Although two members of the board were delegated to request him to withdraw his resignation he refused to do so.

div.head: BRITISH BEER BREWERIES (EGYPT LIMITED)
div.p: Mr. Gerald D.M. Girdwood, director and Mr. W.D.King chief brewer of the British Beer Breweries (Egypt), Limited, have arrived this week in Egypt, to superintend the erection and equipment of the brewery at Shoubra near Cairo. All the necessary plant has been purchased and is on its way from England.

div.head: A NEW ISSUE
div.p: Youssef Bey Saddik, Captain Warren, and other well-known people are about to form a new financial concern under the style of the Financial Corporation of Egypt. The capital will be divided into 397,500 ordinary shares of £1 each and 50,000 founders' shares of 1s each. The object of the company is to undertake every description of financial, land, and other operations.

div.head: UNITED DELTA ENGINEERS LIMITED
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Sir. – Under the heading of "Forthcoming Flotations" in your issue yesterday you state that the British Engineering Co. of Alexandria has been amalgamted with Messrs. Murdoch and templeton, under the title of The United Delta Engineer, Ltd.
You have been wrongly informed. The British Engineering Co. of Alexandria has not been absorbed by the above companies – Yours faithfully,
The British Engineering Co, of Egypt, Ltd.
Meredith Austin,
General Managr
Alexandria 26th February 1907
[The error was due to a misprint. It is the Egyptian Engineering Company which latter is to be one of the companies under the United Delta Engineers, Limited. Ed. E. G]

div.head: MAPLE AND CO, LTD.
div.p: The report to be presented to the abare holders of Maple and Co., Ltd., at the annual general meeting to be held on the company's premises, Tottenham Court Road, London, to-morrow, shows a very satisfactory state of affairs. After placing £10,750 to reserve, the directors are enabled to recommend a dividened to the Ordinary shareholders for the year 1906 of 15 per cent., of which 5 per cent was paid by way of interim dividend on 1st September last. The reserve, now standing at £321,300 will be increased according to the Articles of Association by £10,750 making a total reserve of £332,050.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN EAST AFRICA
div.p: Numerous samples of cotton from the British East Africa Proectorate, including "native," "Egyptian," "American upland," and "Sea Island" varieties have been submitted to the Scientific and Technical Department of the Imperial Insitute for examination and from a report drawn up by Professor Wyndham Dunstan it appears probable that the Egyptian varieties will give the best returns, although the native cottons are of fair quality. A sample of Sea Island cotton from the experimental farm at Malindi was valued at ninepence per pound at a date when "fancy" Georgia Sea Island cotton commanded tenpence halfpenny per pound, but though of fair quality the cotton was of irregular length, and further experiments will be necessary before it can be regarded as definilty established that Sea Island cotton can be grown satisfactorily in British East Africa. Nor have the samples of Egytpian cotton been found equal to the standard sample of "Mitaffi" cotton with which they were compared and while there is every reason to hope that the output of cotton in the Proectorate may be profitably increased, great core needs to be excersied in the purchase and selection of seed for sowing and in the general cultivation and harvesting if Egyptian cotton is to be grown in British East Africa of a quality equal to that of the cotton grown in Egypt.

div.head: A CASE OF SUICIDE
div.p: A passenger who was on board the Papayanni liner Rev M.T.S. Taylor met his death as reported by us yesterday informs us that it was due to a deliberate act of suicide. The sea was not too rough for the passengers to be out on the dock at the time and was not to be compared with the seat on the previous day when the Carpenter was washed overboard. Mr. Taylor had just had tea on deck and then deliberatly jumped overboard. The vessel was stopped and every effort was made to rescure Mr. Taylor, but without success. It was notified to the British Consul at Tangiers that he had committed suicide.

div.head: OBITUARY
MRS. HASELDEN
div.p: We regret to announce the death og Mrs. Joseph Haselden, which took place at Minish yesterday after a few days' illness. Mrs. Haselden was among the oldest members of the British colony in Egypt and was the daughter of Sir Sidney Saunders, K.C.M.G., formerly British Consul General for the City and Port of Alexandria. She married Mr. Jospeh Haselden at Alexandria in 1862 and has been a resident ever since that date in this city, where she has been much loved and respected by a large number of relations and friends. The funeral will take place at 3 o'clock this afternoon from Moharrem Bey Station.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive received yesterday morning in special audience Count valdrome, acting French Diplomatic Agent in Cairo, who presented to his Highness M. Chartrant and M. Edouard Thery.
In the afternoon the Khedive granted private audiences to Yahya Bey Ibrahim and Ahmed Bey Afifi the new president of the Native Court of Appeal and the Mixed Court respectively.

div.head: SPRING IN MARIOUT
div.p: The beautiful weather last Sunday induced numbers of Alexandrians to betake themselves to Mariout, which is now in the heyday of its floral glory. In the neighbourhood of Kingy Mariout, on the shores of the Mediterranean, and also in the desert many well known people were to be found picnicking, for Marriout in the springtime is one of the most beautiful and fragrant districts of Egypt. Mr. H. Bindernagel and his family gave a most successful picnic among the rocks near Amrieh, and Mr. Falls, the German archeaologist, who is at work at old Means City, rode over to join them. A large party of sportsmen started off on Sunday from Mariout to make theur way to Wady Natron and they intend making it a three days' trip.

It is a pity that the Khedive's railway, which runs so conveniently through the district, does not put on more trains on Sundays especially in the spring-time. A special series of Sunday excursion trains ought to be put on and run until one or two weeks after Easter. If these railway facilities were advertised in the local newspapers they should attract numbers of jaded. Alexandrians to make a charming Sunday trip, for Mariout at the present time is incomparable.

div.head: SYRIAN PROGRESS
HARBOUR FOR CAIFFA
div.p: One of the greatest drawbacks to the devleopment of Palestine has been the lack of a good harbour. The authorities are at last waking up to the fact that a proper harbour must be made, especially with a view of the Hedjaz railway traffic and the demand for a trade outlet for the Hauran and Damasons districts. These was an excellent cereal crop last autumn and the want of transport facilities were severely felt. The Turkish authorities have now decided to make a harbour at Caiffa, and Meisner Pasha, the German chief military engineer of the Hedjaz line, has just recieived instructions to begin work there at once.

Meisner Pasha has lond advocated the construction of a larger harbour at Caiffa than the Constantoniple authorities were willing to sanction. An Imperial commission has been studying the question and has ecided that it is to be four times larger than Beyrout harbour, but not as large as the plans of Meisner Pasha.

It is a great pity that the Ottoman authorities could not see their way to adopt the Pasha's plans in their entirety for the geographical position of Caiffa inevitably points to that port in the near future attaining the third rank as a Levant port immeditaly after Alexandria and Smyrna. The Caiffa-Hedjag line will eventually be connected with the Bagdad route if only to facilitate the Persain and Central Asistic pilgrim traffic to Arabia. Then when Jerusalem is a centre of Chrisitan, Jewish and Muslem religions interests and has been joined by railway to Haiffs as must be shortly the western traveller will be able to enjoy all the comforts of occidental travel each as are to be found in Egypt.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SHIPPING CHAMBER
div.p: yesterday afternoon a meeting of the International Chamber of Shipping of Egypt was held at the offices of the Messagerieis Maritimes Company at Alexandria under the presidency of M. Richard. The meeting was attended by the agents of the navigation companies at Alexandria and was convened for the purpose of discussing the conditions of the contracts for berths on the quay.

div.head: BOURSE REGULATIONS
div.p: The corporation of stock and share brokers asked the Government to postpone the time allowed for sending in remarks on the acheme for the new bourse regulations, until the 15th April. The Government, however, has allowed only up to the 15th prox., and it is hoped that the new law will be promulgated before the season comes to a close.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)
Suez, Monday

The outward bound Messageries Maritimes mailsteamer Polynesian received some damage in the Canal, and apparently had one of her propeller blades broken. She is now moored in the North Basin of Port Ibrahim at Suez for repairs and will very likely sail for Djibouti on Thursday next. In the meantime many of her passengers have proceeded to Cairo.
The S.S. Candleshoe, which was ashore at Ras Dib, in the Gulf of Suez has been successfully refloated and returned to Suez to day for repairs.

div.head: ARABIC LITERARY HISTORY
div.p: Mr. Uwin has in the press a new volume in his "Library of Literary History" – 'A Literary History of the Arabs', by the well-known Oriental scholar Mr. R.A. Nicholson. In it Mr. Nicholson has sketched the history of Arabian thought in its broad outlines from the earliest times to the present day and illustrated the subject as far as posible by translations of typical passages in Aranic literature. Beginning with a chapter on the ancient inhabitants of Arabia Felix, he has devoted considerable space to the history, legends and poetry of the Pagan Arabs, as well as the political and religious sects which arose during the early Mohamedan period. The second half of the volume deals with 'The Golden Age of Islam,' 'The Decline and Fall of the Caliphate,' and the subsequent history of the Arabs under foreign rule.

div.head: Steam Ploughing Machinery
NOTICE
div.p: Messrs. Allen, Alderson and Co., Limited, Alexandria and Cairo have the pleasure of advise their friends and all persons interested in agriculture that Mr. Alfred Fowler a director of Messrs. Joh Fowler and Co., Ltd., the well-known makes of steam ploughing machinery is now in Cairo as is also Mr. H.C. Duburgnet, an engineer and expert of the same firm. Mr. Fowler is staying at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, and Mr. Duberguet at Shepheard's. Both gentleman who have a large and varied experience all over the world, will be very pleased to inspect estates at their own expense entirlely and adivse as to the best steam cultivating machinery to be employed to obtain the best reults at the cheapest cost. Messrs. John Fowler and Co., Ltd., will have a good disply at the Cairo Show from the 28th Februray to the 4th March and will be pleased to give every information to interested persons.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Many happy returns of the day to Lord Cromer, who was born at Cromer Hall, Norfolk, on the 26th February, 1841.
Prince d'Arenberg, chairmen of the Suez Canal Company, has left Port Said for Europe by the S.S. Seydlitz

Lady Carolin Gordon-Lennox, who is only sister to the Duke of Richmond, and Lady Helen Lennox, the Duke's youngesy and only unmarriesd daughter have we are glad to say, found Lady Muriel Beckwith, Lady Helen's older sister, much better. Mr. William Beckwith, as most of our readers will know, is quartered here with the Coldstream Guards and great anxiety had been felt concerning Lady Muriel's health.

Lady Caroline is a very capable and cultured woman, who is devoted to her four motherless nieces (her brother, the present Duke has been twice widowed), and before the marriage of the three eldest often acted as their chaperone. From the time of her mother's death, twenty years ago, until the death of her father in 1903 she was the latter's constant companion. Her home is now in Wilton-crescent but she is often her brother's guest at Goodwood or Gordon Castle
Hussein Pasha Moharrem, chief A.D.C. to he Khedive, has retired on pension.
"Al Makattam" learns that Adly Pasha yaghen, Director General of Wakts, will resign his post shortly in order ot devote his time to financial affairs. His successor has not yet been nominated.

Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria requests us thank all his friends and acquaintances who were kind enough to enquire after his state of health during his recent illness, The enquiries have besn so numerous that he is unable to return thanks individually.

Sir Charles Wyndham entertained a party at dinner at the Savoy Restaurant last night. Amongst the guests were: Lord Edward Cecil, Hon. Alex York, Capt. and Mrs. Rome, Sir James Blyth, Miss Bluth, Col. and Mrs. J.K. Watson Pasha, Miss Mary Moore and Mrs. Fred Scotter.
Mr and Mrs. Loeb entertained Harari Pasha and Mr. and Mrs. Straus
Col. and Lady Greanville Smith entertained a party in one of the private dining-rooms of the Savoy Hotel.

The Rt. Rev. Bishop J. Taylor Smith C.V.O., D.D. Chaplain General to the Forces same down to Alexandria from Cairo yesterday on inspective duty on the completion of which he will embark on the transport Sicilia for England
Captain and Mrs. Reaves (nee E'sie Allen of Bulkeley) are now at Colombo where Captain Reeves is stationed with his battery.
Captain Rickard and Captain Molesworth of the Royal Irish Fusiliers who are both convalescent after their recent illness are going home on leave by the troopship Sicilia to-morrow.
Mrs. Wain and her daughter have left the Savoy for a short stay in Upper Egypt.

Mr. A. Wild the popular manager of the Savoy Hotel has taken over in connection with his brothers, the National Hotel at Zurich. This will be good news to Savoyards who visit Switzerlandd, for Mr. Wild's management of the Savoy is always greatyl appreciated, We shall, however, still have hime among is for the winter months.
Dr. Harold Benjamin Day has been authorised to practices in Egypt.

Among the latest arrivals at the Semiramis Hotel we note: – Miss H.M. Gould of the well-known Gould family; Mr and Mrs. O. de St. Ivany, Budapest; Mr. Brun, chamberlain to H. M. the King of Denmark, and Mrs. Brun; Mr. and Mrs. C. Johnson, Mr. C. Meyer Gaschwitz, New York; Comte and Comtesses de la Riveliere, Sir Robert Dashwood, Bart., Sir William and Lady Geary, General Mahmoud Mukhtar Pasha, Mr. and Mrs. Said Sabit Bey, Baron A. de Meussor, Mr and Mrs. von Techudi, Capt. and Mrs. Moberly, Mr. and Mrs. Anderson and family, Capt. and Mrs. Thompson, Dr. Carthy Morrogh, Mr. and Mrs. A. Tilche, Lady Brookelehurst, Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Hardie.

The Austrian Lloyd steamer Imperatrix is regarded as a total loss. The captain and all the officers and passengers, except the third engineer and the majority of the crew have been brought here. Thirty-nine of the crew including 8 Lascars, have been drowned. (R.)
The number of victims of the disaster to the Imperatrix is 40 seamen. (Havas)

The "Times" leanrs from Tangier that the representatives of the European Powers will address two collective notes to the Maghzen, the first insisting on the termination of the anarchy resiging in Mogador, and the second reminding that certain clauses of the Algeciras Convention have not yet been enforced. (R)
The company of the State Bank of Morocco has been definitely constituted. (Havas)

The Emperor receiving the president and vice-president of the new Reichstag, declared that the elections had shown that social-democracy could be everyone. He hoped that the German people would realize this at last.(R)
The Emperor William received the president and vice-president of the Reichstag. Examining the situation be drew therefrom conclusions favourable to peace.
In the Reichstag Prince von Bulow explained the Government's policy. He considered possible the realisation of a fruitful policy with the support of the present majority (H)
The sudden successive deaths of the Turkish Admirals Hairi Pasha and Sami Pasha is provoking much comment here. (Reuter)

div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's ail. The supplement contains exhausation and important reviews of the cotton, cotton need and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the vening of the preceding day, complete labuorar forms of the various market fluctuations and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Asssociation, etc. etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (of postage in Egypt- for abroad the postage is P.T. extra) For further particualrs apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette"

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers “Osiris" and “Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy’s most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, “Entombment," by Ciseri, and ‘Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D’OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
